content.body: Domenic: is https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8467 in your queue?

> <@annevk:matrix.org> Domenic: is https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8467 in your queue?

No.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
Domenic: is https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8467 in your queue?
No.

content.body: Domenic: let me rephrase that, do you want to look at it before it lands?
content.formatted_body: Domenic: let me rephrase that, do you want to look at it before it lands?

content.body: Since you reviewed it before.
Nah, seems fine. Although I'm not sure it actually has Chrome support at the moment.
Chrome engineers drove the change with the CSS WG. If you want to double check on that I can hold off on landing this. Let me know.
Yeah we should hold off. They're failing to get signoff on blink-dev last I saw.

keithamus: I'm gonna wait with another round of review for EventTarget until it's a bit more established what the API shape should be. One thing that did seem to be missing is the parent setter/getter definition.
content.formatted_body: keithamus: I'm gonna wait with another round of review for EventTarget until it's a bit more established what the API shape should be. One thing that did seem to be missing is the parent setter/getter definition.

content.body: annevk: within `EventTarget`? or `EventTargetInternals`?
I've updated which hopefully clarifies the steps for get/set on `EventTargetInternals` `parent`.
content.formatted_body: I've updated which hopefully clarifies the steps for get/set on EventTargetInternals parent.

content.body: Jake Archibald: I cannot reply to https://twitter.com/jaffathecake/status/1711872418434654419 but isn't the problem Chromium here, perhaps? I wonder what happens in the non-Chromium URLPattern implementation. Custom URL schemes are supported pretty well in URL and the idea is that they are too in URLPattern, provided you have a compliant URL parser.
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: I cannot reply to https://twitter.com/jaffathecake/status/1711872418434654419 but isn't the problem Chromium here, perhaps? I wonder what happens in the non-Chromium URLPattern implementation. Custom URL schemes are supported pretty well in URL and the idea is that they are too in URLPattern, provided you have a compliant URL parser.

content.body: annevk: ohhh, my understanding was that if you use a non http(s) scheme then the rest of the URL won't be parsed by HTTP rules
content.formatted_body: annevk: ohhh, my understanding was that if you use a non http(s) scheme then the rest of the URL won't be parsed by HTTP rules

content.body: Jake Archibald: see https://jsdom.github.io/whatwg-url/ as an easy way to test specific inputs; generally when people complain about this they are talking about a long-standing Chromium and Gecko bug
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: see https://jsdom.github.io/whatwg-url/ as an easy way to test specific inputs; generally when people complain about this they are talking about a long-standing Chromium and Gecko bug

content.body: I was hoping that Interop 2023 would fix it, but it seems like it will be at least another year

content.body: If a request from a document goes through a service worker, what's the `client` set to of the request that finally makes it to the "HTTP-network-or-cache fetch" algorithm (assuming the service worker did a `respondWith(fetch(e.request))`? Is it the original document's ESO, or the service worker's? After reading https://w3c.github.io/ServiceWorker/#on-fetch-request-algorithm I'm almost positive the answer is "the original document global".
content.formatted_body: If a request from a document goes through a service worker, what's the client set to of the request that finally makes it to the "HTTP-network-or-cache fetch" algorithm (assuming the service worker did a respondWith(fetch(e.request))? Is it the original document's ESO, or the service worker's? After reading https://w3c.github.io/ServiceWorker/#on-fetch-request-algorithm I'm almost positive the answer is "the original document global".
